Growing uncertainties such as protectionism and trade tensions are likely to challenge business investments. Because businesses are embedded in the world economy, they are sensitive to such international developments 4/4

Private consumption is affected by changes to real disposable income – how much people can spend in addition to their basic living-costs. Real disposable income is increasingly driven by wage developments instead of employment growth: this is slowing down private consumption 3/4 https://t.co/7AIYvu3xb5

Domestic demand depends on private consumption and business investment: this means GDP growth is supported by both the amount of money people spend and businesses’ investment decisions. Both are challenged by current developments inside and outside the eurozone 2/4
Speech Pentti Hakkarainen: “The banking union option – observations from my experience” https://t.co/UkaufbAlZb

Lautenschläger: European banks are more robust today. That doesn’t mean that everyone has done all their homework or that we can sit back and say that everything is perfect now. That’s never the case for banking supervisors 4/4

Lautenschläger: In banking supervison you're dealing with people – if you don't like confrontation, you're in the wrong place. You have to show you're assertive, that you can say no, that you will keep on asking precise questions and will not be satisfied with vague answers 3/4

Lautenschläger: If you never questioned your own role you would not be the right person for the job. For each and every one of the decisions we take, I naturally ask myself: What is my task? What interests are at stake? What is my statutory mandate? 2/4

(THREAD) European banks are more resilient today than they were in 2008, says Sabine Lautenschläger. But how has banking supervision changed? And what makes a good banking supervisor? Read on to find out more and check out the full interview https://t.co/0KNF7VnS4A 1/4 https://t.co/J1Hqv5b4F3

@SavasKarakapln If banknote manufacturers produce souvenir banknotes, they must comply with the ECB reproduction rules to ensure that the banknotes cannot be mistaken as genuine. Here are the rules https://t.co/ApZoUbZBxm

@SavasKarakapln The ECB does not regulate or approve souvenir banknotes like the one featuring Ataturk. The only euro banknotes recognised by the ECB as legal tender are issued by the national central banks in the euro area.

@TheEgeEye If banknote manufacturers produce souvenir banknotes, they must comply with the ECB reproduction rules to ensure that the banknotes cannot be mistaken as genuine. Here are the rules https://t.co/ApZoUbI0FO

@TheEgeEye The ECB does not regulate or approve souvenir banknotes like the one featuring Ataturk. The only euro banknotes recognised by the ECB as legal tender are issued by the national central banks in the euro area.

Europäische Banken sind seit 2008 krisenfester geworden. Aber wie hat sich die Bankenaufsicht verändert? Und was macht gute Bankenaufseher aus? Das ganze Interview von Sabine Lautenschläger mit @hrinfo zum Hören https://t.co/S1zvWLFWro und Nachlesen https://t.co/ntHyJX5xOl https://t.co/f7lQ1Z7CPa
@riseforrohan Yes, the #ECBForum on Central Banking is an annual event. It has taken place every year since 2014.

Are you a PhD student in economics or finance? Apply now for a chance to present your research to policymakers and top academics at this year’s #ECBForum in Portugal. The final winner of the competition will be awarded €10,000. More info https://t.co/TqVH4e0KGB #EUROat20 https://t.co/AgC1KhJyB1

But don’t worry! Not every stained banknote is useless! If there are only very light stains – similar to the ones on this €20 note – the marks are most likely accidental: the money should still be usable so you don’t need to worry about accepting it https://t.co/nNdF4YO5Wg https://t.co/GlCjRW6JKz

Did you know it is probably stolen money? The green stain is security ink – released if criminals break into a protected cash container such as an ATM. Do you know what to do if someone gives you a banknote covered with ink? Find out here https://t.co/aOgJyVzRM5
Have you ever seen a banknote that looks like this? https://t.co/vd9dECY2Mh

Benoît Cœuré: Upgrading and interconnecting our payment systems can limit the use of “shadow payments”. 3/3
Benoît Cœuré: Failing to address financial exclusion may favour unregulated and potentially unsafe “shadow payments” such as cryptocurrencies. 2/3

(THREAD) Benoît Cœuré speech “Fintech for the people” in Cape Town: Financial exclusion is a threat to social cohesion, education and jobs in developing economies. Read the full speech https://t.co/qLncuHwRey 1/3 https://t.co/IPM6GfTSq6
Want to find out more about how monetary policy helps to reduce inequality? Take a look at the working paper on the subject https://t.co/0HcxmTqD06

Watch our video – published last July – to find out more about how monetary policy helps to reduce inequality. Since the video’s statistics cut-off date, employment in the euro area has further increased: there are now 9.6 million more people in a job than there were in 2013. https://t.co/PJ1inMERdp

ECB asset purchases have reduced inequality in the eurozone, our research shows. They have especially benefited low-income households, which suffer the most from unemployment. Full Research Bulletin here https://t.co/MlMQO2BXxK https://t.co/4DtpcOsqms

Don’t miss your chance to share your feedback! Which ESTER-based methodology would be best suited for producing a fallback rate for EURIBOR-linked contracts? Do new term rates need to be defined for different products? The consultation closes this Friday https://t.co/GVThtga0uq https://t.co/sT9yn4MV7Q

#ESTER, the new euro short-term rate, is coming later this year and will replace #EONIA. What is the best way for markets to make the transition? Read the report by the working group on euro risk-free rates and share your comments by this Friday https://t.co/Kh7hLctxRh https://t.co/NKO8QYEHVJ
Interview Benoît Cœuré with Bloomberg TV https://t.co/Xesq4FCxjG

Do you know how to spot a counterfeit? Our banknotes contain multiple security features so you can be sure they are genuine. Use the “feel, look and tilt” method to distinguish a counterfeit from a genuine banknote. See here https://t.co/Bnfqi6dMmv

The likelihood of receiving a counterfeit banknote remains low: in the second half of 2018, 27.8% fewer counterfeit banknotes were detected compared with the second half of the previous year. Read more https://t.co/MpIm8CQRnR https://t.co/MIAUItfR1U

Hi, we’re the ECB. You may know us from our #GreatestHits “we actually don’t know much about cricket”, “Draghi’s tie is not a monetary policy message” and our hit single “keeping prices stable since 1999” @ECB_cricket #draghitieguesses #EUROat20

⚡️Missed yesterday’s press conference? Catch up here!
https://t.co/WqEmua2Q1T
https://t.co/kvvLNCy2Ua
Transcript with Q&A of yesterday’s monetary policy press conference https://t.co/nOKNN1rDSG https://t.co/GPlhaTRq1U
Watch again: Draghi on whether there’s a sense in the Governing Council that his successor should be found more quickly https://t.co/yaAaCdLSP8
Watch again: Draghi on political commitment to deepening Economic and Monetary Union https://t.co/ZylTD0WjKZ
Watch again: Draghi on the effectiveness of LTROs and TLTROs https://t.co/i35eeiaxC5
Watch again: Draghi on why banks are better equipped to deal with a possible downturn https://t.co/KHTzieJ5Cr
Watch again: Draghi on the instruments the ECB stands ready to use if necessary https://t.co/blnSA5wzUA
Draghi: Euro has highest approval rate in its history
Draghi: Some parts of the euro area are at full employment
Draghi: We have a long list of instruments and we stand ready to use them, adjust them according to the contingency that is produced
Draghi: LTROs and TLTROs have been very useful and very effective in restoring transmission of monetary policy in euro area

Draghi: We’ll continue to monitor the profitability of the banking sector very closely ... Banks are stronger now than before the crisis and a strong banking sector is key for making sure that a downturn does not turn into a recession
Draghi: Bank Lending Survey points to slight tightening mainly in Italy, not rest of the euro area
Draghi: Fiscal policy in the euro area is more expansionary than last year
Draghi: By and large the banking sector is much stronger than before the beginning of the crisis
Draghi: There was unanimity in the Governing Council that the likelihood of a recession is low
Introductory statement Mario Draghi to the press conference https://t.co/nOKNN1rDSG
Draghi: We were unanimous about acknowledging the weaker momentum and changing the balance of risk for growth
Draghi: Today we did not discuss the implications, the meeting was devoted to assessment, where are we, why are we here, how long will the slow down last

Draghi: The economic and monetary analysis confirms an ample degree of monetary accommodation is still necessary for the continued sustained convergence of inflation to levels that are below, but close to, 2% over the medium term
Draghi: Underlying inflation is expected to increase over the medium term, supported by our monetary policy measures, the ongoing economic expansion and rising wage growth

Draghi: The risks surrounding the euro area growth outlook have moved to the downside on account of the persistence of uncertainties related to geopolitical factors and the threat of protectionism, vulnerabilities in emerging markets and financial market volatility

Draghi: In any event, the Governing Council stands ready to adjust all of its instruments, as appropriate, to ensure that inflation continues to move towards our inflation objective in a sustained manner

Draghi: Significant monetary policy stimulus remains essential to support the further build-up of domestic price pressures and headline inflation developments over the medium term. This will be provided by our forward guidance, reinforced by the reinvestments
Draghi: Supportive financing conditions, favourable labour market dynamics and rising wage growth continue to underpin the euro area expansion and gradually rising inflation pressures
Draghi: The persistence of uncertainties in particular relating to geopolitical factors and the threat of protectionism is weighing on economic sentiment
Draghi: Incoming information has continued to be weaker than expected on account of softer external demand and some country and sector-specific factors

Draghi: We intend to continue reinvesting, in full, the principal payments from maturing securities purchased under the asset purchase programme for an extended period of time past the date when we start raising the key ECB interest rates, and in any case for as long as necessary

Draghi: We continue to expect key ECB interest rates to remain at their present levels at least through the summer of 2019, and in any case for as long as necessary to ensure the continued sustained convergence of inflation to our objective over the medium term
